title: Cardioembolic Aphasia Raddle
clue1: In nonvalvular {W}, thrombus often forms in the left atrial appendage and can become this traveling clot.
clue2: A cardioembolic {W} commonly lodges in the proximal anterior circulation—classically the ____ artery.
clue3: Dominant-hemisphere {W} occlusion often causes this language deficit.
clue4: In expressive {W}, the lesion localizes to this eponymous language area.
clue5: {W} area sits in the inferior frontal gyrus, part of the ____ lobe.
clue6: The {W} lobe’s lateral surface includes this cortex “cap” over the insula involved in speech production.
clue7: The {W} overlies the insula; the insula is supplied by deep perforators called ____ arteries.
